Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(2) Summary

APIs are the digital glue for how companies operate and collaborate today. This marks a fundamental shift from the original idea of APIs as technical interconnections to one of APIs as the business building blocks of digital transformation. What does this shift mean for our API practices? First and foremost, this means that thinking about an API's business value must be a fundamental part of API inception and design. But it also means that we have to think of APIs as products, meaning that good APIs should be reusable so that they become building blocks with a bigger potential. These API products need to be discoverable because APIs only create value when they are being used. This means that portals, catalogs, and marketplaces should become part of the standard API toolbox so that APIs can be easily created, published, found, tried out, and used. This end-to-end view of APIs is what we mean when we talk about a good API: It's an API that is created with a purpose and within an environment that helps making the most out of this purpose.



Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

Myth #1: APIs are about Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(6) A Brief History of APIs

  • Local APIs have been used since the 1940s
  • Network APIs have been used since the 1950s
  • Network APIs used to be called Protocols
  • Salesforce launched what they called APIs in February 2000
  • eBay launched their APIs in November 2000


Myth #1: APIs are about Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(7) APIs Create Modular and Scalable Businesses

  • Digital Transformation
  • Move fast and break things
  • Loose coupling
  • The composable enterprise
  • The platform economy
  • The hockey stick


Myth #1: APIs are about Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(8) Digital Transformation Definition

Digital Transformation means adapting an organization's strategy and structure to capture opportunities enabled by digital technology. (Nathan Furr and Andrew Shipilov, Digital Doesn't Have to Be Disruptive, Harvard Business Review 97(4), July/August 2019, pp. 94-103) [https://hbr.org/2019/07/digital-doesnt-have-to-be-disruptive]

(13) The 900lb Gorilla



Myth #2: API Monetization Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(14) Most API Value Creation is Indirect

  1. Using APIs to become better at internal reuse and cross-pollination
  2. Reducing friction by having teams communicate via APIs
  3. Using API First as a way to build everything as digital building blocks

Myth #3: API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(16) What is a Platform?

  1. A runtime platform that provides support for running applications
  2. A service platform for developing decentralized applications
  3. A business platform as a specific way to run & scale a business


Myth #3: API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(17) (One) Platform Definition

A platform is a business model that facilitates the exchange of value between two or more user groups, a consumer and a producer. In order to make these exchanges happen, platforms harness and create large, scalable networks of users and resources that can be accessed on demand. Platforms create communities and markets that allow users to interact and transact. […] Platforms don't, to use a common phrase, own the means of production—instead, they create the means of connection. (Alex Moazed and Nicholas L. Johnson, Modern Monopolies, St. Martin's Press, 2016 [https://us.macmillan.com/books/9781250091901/modernmonopolies])



Myth #3: API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(18) But we're not Uber…

  • Pure platform businesses are fascinating but rare
  • Find a way how to create platformish parts of your value streams
  • Business input is essential and APIs are just the means to an end

Tunnel Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(21) One Tunnel to Call them All



Tunnel Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(22) Distributed Programming

  • Distribution and Decentralization are two distinct patterns
  • Rooted in Remote Procedure Call (RPC) approaches of the 1980s
  • Functions are the main abstraction calls are tunneled to the server
  • A good fit for developers looking to write a distributed program

(24) Listing All Resources



Resource Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(25) Identifiers for Resources

  • Providing globally identified resources that support interactions
  • Resources ideally are defined through a user-centric design process
  • API Stories help explaining how to walk across resources

Hypermedia Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(27) Linking All Resources



Hypermedia Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(28) Hypermedia APIs

  • Resources contain hypermedia controls for next steps
  • Workflows are designed into the API
  • Hypermedia API landscapes fell like one huge API
  • Developers can have a hard time letting go of controlling the flow

Query Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(30) Querying into Server-Side Models



Query Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(31) Querying Structured Data

  • Good for APIs with a vast interconnected data space
  • APIs are based on a generic data model and matching query language
  • Challenging learning curve for complex data models
  • Change management and security are non-trivial

Event-Based Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(33) Event Publish/Subscribe



Event-Based Style Erik Wilde (@dret): What is a Good API?

(34) Reversing Control

  • Good fit when actions originate on the server
  • Requires an event fabric to deliver events to consumers
  • Big range of models from per API to Event Service Bus (ESB)
  • Used more for private than for partner/public APIs
